content:
I think the example in the statement is confusing and ambiguous. At first, I thought it was trying to explain that for the example below where max distance is 2, that (5,10) and (10,5) is a pair but clearly 10-5 is not <= 2 which is what confused me. After re-reading it now, I understand it is defining a pair in general.

Update: I added the definition of a pair above the example for clarity. Hopefully it will make more sense.

The constraint on N is inadequate. It indicates that one should implement a more efficient solution (because O(n^2) won't pass by the time), even thought it is not necessary since N is never greater than 500.

Could you change the constraints?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The logic is well defined and it can be solved in multiple ways, it can also be improved to force more optimized solutions but so far it is good as it is

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is pretty challenging, it is linear to solve, basically it needs a nested cycle in order to get all the pair, do the difference and count it only if a-b <= d.
it sounds good, it can be reasonably resolved in 15 minutes

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good Luck and good job!

In Goals section you use the expression "<" (aka "less than") but in Input and Output section you say "maximum difference" and "a difference less than or equal to"

So I think you need to change Goals section to "<="
(Or is it "=<")

Are all the numbers in L guaranteed to be different?
If so, I think you should say that.

If not, I think you should explain what to do in an case where there is a duplicate:
For example, in a List of 
5 1 2 3 4 5
Is (5,5) a "pair" in this case?
You are using "pairs" and "couple", seemingly to mean the same thing.  I think you need to pick just one of those (I like "pair") and stick with it.

In the input section
 - I would put first [[d]], then [[n]], and then the list (to avoid having the size of the list being too far from the list itself).
 - please replace "1st Line :" by "Line 1:", "2nd Line :" by "Line 2:" etc.

In the Goal section, in your example, you forgot to mention that d=2. I recommend
<<For example>> if [[L]] = 4 5 6 10 2 3 and [[d]] = 2

Reverse mode seems impossible to me... I suggest you remove it.

Suggestion for the title: bounded differences (différences bornées).

* Lots of translation weirdness: "Given a list [[L]] of [[n]] integers, print the number of pairs {{a}} and {{b}} in [[L]] where {{a - b < [[d]]}}" (the word "difference" is wrong).

* Similarly in terms of translation, "Warning" should be "Note" or "For example." I would word this sentence as "For example, if [[L]] is {{4 5 6 10 2 3}}:"

* Last big translation issue: what does the title mean?

* Test cases should be better matched to their validators: [[n]] should be about the same if not equal, and the outputs should be similar as well.

Please refer to the contribution guidelines and follow the example there for the presentation of the Input and Output section:
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/statement#guidelines

e.g. <<Line 1:>> An integer [[n]] for the number of integers in the list.

After you have indicated all the variable types in Input section, the constraint "[[d]] is a integer" can be removed.

Thanks.
Thank you for your advice! Is it better this way?
